Award.AwardTitle: Efficient Energy Release Rate Computations for Cracks with Arbitrary Location and Geometry

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this fracture mechanics project is to utilize the topological derivative to approximate the energy release rate (ERR) field associated with a (small) crack of arbitrary parameterized geometry. The proposed method is radically different from, and substantially more efficient than, conventional finite element method (FEM), generalized FEM and extended FEM treatment of fracture problems. Indeed, it eliminates the need to discretize the cracked structural component. Rather it provides an approximation of the ERR for a crack of arbitrary geometry located anywhere in the solid by simply evaluate the stress field present in the loaded un-cracked component. This analysis needs to be conducted only once and with a finite element mesh substantially coarser than that needed to model the cracked specimen (since there is no need to capture the stress concentration at a crack front). Moreover it uses conventional FEA methods and thereby it eliminates the need for specialty elements. Ultimately it will be used to generate finite element contour plots that illustrate critical crack geometries throughout the body. Whence, potential failure locations and critical inspection sites can be readily identified. In this proposal, the preliminary results that are limited to 2-D homogenous isotropic linear elastic structures will be extended to heterogeneous, anisotropic, nonlinear three-dimensional structures. Moreover, the first-order approximation will be extended to achieve second-order accuracy.

The successful completion of this project will lead to a novel computational design tool that is substantially more efficient than conventional. By substantially facilitating the fracture-based analysis of structural components, the method is expected to have a major impact in all industries for which the design of structural components is dictated by the presence of critical flaws. The method will also be incorporated in the graduate course on fracture mechanics that attracts students from across the College of Engineering. Through the office of Engineering On-Line Education at the University of Illinois, this course will be made available outside the University, and especially to Minority Serving Institutions (MSI).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The energy release rate (ERR) is one of the key quantities entering the analysis of fracture problems, as it corresponds to the energy available for crack propagation and is a function of the size, location and orientation of the crack, the geometry of the structural component and the loading conditions. When an analyst tries to determine whether a crack or defect present in a structure is critical (i.e., will propagate), he/she compares the ERR to the fracture toughness of the material, which corresponds to the energy required for crack propagation. Estimating numerically the ERR for complex 3D structures under complex loading conditions using conventional methods is time consuming as it involves the creation of a very fine mesh focused at the tip of the crack for every potential location and orientation of the edge crack, and then the solution of a new finite element model of the cracked domain.

 

The new method avoids all these challenges by instead estimating the ERR using a single finite element analysis of the uncracked domain (which can be discretized with a coarser mesh) and a formulation based on topological derivatives. As alluded to above, the method offers significant computational advantages over conventional methods because (i) it requires only a single analysis while other methods require an analysis for each combination of location and orientation, and (ii) it is performed on the non-cracked domain, removing the need to create very fine meshes in the vicinity of crack tips.

 

This NSF-sponsored project has led to two major advances. The first one involves the formulation of the ERR approximation using higher-order topological derivatives, which allows for the accurate treatment of longer cracks (compared to the other dimensions of the structure) than the first-order approximation involved in the previous formulation. The second and more important contribution consists in the extension of the method to arbitrary 3D problems, where the efficiency of the method is particularly attractive as both the meshing and solution steps are substantially more time consuming in 3D than in 2D. We also developed as part of this project a graphical User interface (GUI) allowing the analyst to create a natural link between the solution of a 2D structural analysis performed with a commercial finite element solver (Abaqus) and the extraction of the energy release rate at any location along outer and inner boundaries.

 

Future efforts involve (i) extending the GUI to 3D, (ii) technology transfer to industry through the NSF I-Corps program, and (iii) combining the ERR estimate based on topological derivatives with shape optimization to design fracture-resistant structures.

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2017
Modified by: Philippe H Geubelle

When an analyst tries to determine whether a crack or defect present in a structure is critical (i.e., will propagate), he/she compares the ERR to the fracture toughness of the material, which corresponds to the energy required for crack propagation. The new method avoids all these challenges by instead estimating the ERR using a single finite element analysis of the uncracked domain (which can be discretized with a coarser mesh) and a formulation based on topological derivatives. As alluded to above, the method offers significant computational advantages over conventional methods because (i) it requires only a single analysis while other methods require an analysis for each combination of location and orientation, and (ii) it is performed on the non-cracked domain, removing the need to create very fine meshes in the vicinity of crack tips. This NSF-sponsored project has led to two major advances. The first one involves the formulation of the ERR approximation using higher-order topological derivatives, which allows for the accurate treatment of longer cracks (compared to the other dimensions of the structure) than the first-order approximation involved in the previous formulation. Future efforts involve (i) extending the GUI to 3D, (ii) technology transfer to industry through the NSF I-Corps program, and (iii) combining the ERR estimate based on topological derivatives with shape optimization to design fracture-resistant structures.
